title: Dog walkers in Northumberland on 'high alert' after poison scare
text:
Play video Northumbria Police has warned dog walkers to be vigilant and report any suspicious activity after a dog fell ill in Hexham after eating slug pellets.
It comes just over a week after another dog died and two others had seizures after taking a walk on a riverside path in Ovingham.
At this stage, the two incidents are not being linked, but dog walkers in the area have told ITV New Tyne Tess that they are concerned.
One dog owner at Hexham's Tyne Green said: "I took them from here and I took them up to the Sele and two dog walkers stopped me and said they'd found pellets on the top of the Sele and a man was actually taking them down and was going to get them analysed, so I had to take my dogs from there. I'm thinking where can I walk my dogs now?"
Another concerned owner said: "We're quite concerned because one of our dogs will go for any kind of food and if they run of the lead, you don't see where they're going."
This latest suspected poisoning comes less than two week after three dogs suffered seizures after walking on an Ovingham riverside path.
One of those dogs, Scrumpy, sadly died.
Scrumpy died after suffering a seizure shortly a walk in Ovingham. Vets can't link the incidents, but admit slug pellets would cause symptoms like seizures.
The chemical Metaldehyde found in slug pellets is very toxic to dogs. It causes neurological symptoms, it can be a very rapid onset, so within half an hour of them eating the slug pellets they can start to show signs.
"These can range from just tremors and twitching, but it can get worse and go to full convulsions and seizures which are life threatening."
– Helena Guest, Scott Mitchell Associates Vets A sample of the slug pellets found at Tyne Green Northumberland County Council removed the pellets which were found on Tuesday from the Tyne Green site.
Police are warning dog walkers to remain vigilant and report any suspicious activity.Officers are making further enquiries and will continue to patrol the affected area.
